Sandycane

...'It's not just a book! It's a weapon to control the minds of the weak and desperate.'
 
 These words were spoken by the charachter, Carnegie (Gary Oldman) when asked why he so desperately wanted the last remaining copy of the KJV of the bible that was in the possession of Eli (Denzel Washington).
 
 Here is a condensed version of the movie (spoiler alert): The Book of Eli - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
 
 ...and when the movie was over, this was pretty much it and I didn't care for it...but, after giving it some serious thought, about what wasn't said outright in the movie, the between-the-lines implications, I'd have to say it was a pretty good and accurate depiction of the human species...how even after global war and destruction, and an attempt to destroy all traces of religion (the bible), there still remains those who desire to control 'the weak and desperate' with the aid of an invisible power - one, supposedly for good the other, supposedly for evil...but both for the purpose of power over and control of people.
 
 As in the 'real world', there is always some disaster and dispair and there are basically three types of human: Those who look to others for a solution to their problems and those who attempt to solve the problems for themselves - and those who try to control both through manipulation, deception, fear, guilt or brute force.
 
 Overall, I would have to give this movie emoticon_xgoodemoticon_xgood ...eventhough I couldn't say I 'liked' the movie because it was sadly too close to the reality of the 'real world'.
 
 Even after a global war that was blamed on religion (the bible) and an attempt was made to wipe it from the face of the earth (along with nearly everything else that was destroyed by the blast), and humanity has an opportunity to rebuild a new world, literally from scratch, the same scenario begins to play out - like a broken record - de jevue, all over again. emoticon_cry
 
 Is this our only destiny? emoticon_ic
Sandycane

 I saw it with low expectations and was surprised at how much better it was. I think they could have developed the story a little more, but I would recommend it for the story.
 
 As long as one man fears going without and another wants more than the next we will have the same in one form or another.
 
 Our emotions make us and break us.
simone

The premise of the movie is founded upon total falsehood. In the midst of disaster, survivors are far more likely to become more, and extremely more so, religious.
 
 Observe what happened in Haiti when the survivors gathered in the ruins of their churches to pray and sing hymns.
 
 I understand that the cinematography is outstanding -- though Washington must have been a bit desperate to do the role.
 
 Although I can understand why he chose to do it, an African American seldom gets a chance to play such a heroic and studly role in cinema. On that basis, I'd give Washington a pass.
 
 On the other hand, after the horrific events of September 11, 2001, when Saudi Arabian religious extremists attacked out nation I cursed God and all religions, founded as they are on ruthless diversity and endless warfare.
 
 Just look at the history of Ireland.
 
 Or Kosovo.
 
 Or the Middle East where even Muslims choose to bomb the bejesus out of each other over a ancient and trivial religious dispute.
 
 Religion totally sucks.
 
 And, even in the face of extreme events as depicted in the Book of Eli, I'd still hang on to my KJV bible simply because I love the elegance of the language in which it was written.

 23 Minutes in HELL, by Bill Wiese, he explains the torments of what Hell is like
 
 Bill (Wiese) was given a 23 minute tour of Hell with Jesus Christ, and tells about the absolute unspeakable misery that lost souls have to endure. You've never heard anything like this before!... Bill Wiese saw the searing flames of hell, felt total isolation, and experienced the putrid and rotting stench, deafening screams of agony, terrorizing demons, and finally, the strong hand of God lifting him out of the pit.  Well I'm sure you're not surprised that I disagree with those last two sentences. :) 
 The reality is that it's really only relatively recently (compared with all of history) that non-religious elements of society--secular govt. for instance--have even thought to bother itself with organized humanitarian and compassionate causes in any meaningful way. It has pretty much been religion, most of the time. Even the Enlightenment itself came about largely because of a religious event: the protestant reformation. And due largely to religious undercurrents by religious people like John Locke and various religious scientists. (Among numerous other factors too, of course)
 I just don't think secular society is there yet, on its own. If somehow organized religion disappeared off the earth suddenly, yeah, I really do believe human society would pretty much turn into a hellish world rather quickly. And I think history bears that opinion out. Of course, there's no way to prove it, either way.
 Not to say that organized religion hasn't caused its share of problems too, of course.

Zardoz

As an anti-theist and collector of apocalyptic fiction (hobby), I saw both sides of the coin.
 
 The story of 'Eli' was one of the power of faith and it's (supposed) triumph over evil.
 
 Oldman wanted to use the power of the bible to control and sway the masses.
 Yet, through the mystical power of god, he was denied.
 A blind messenger repeatedly defeated Oldmans forces up until the end when, in an act to life the message of the bible, he turns the book over to the enemy to do as he pleased. But, the enemy was foiled as the book was writen in brail...and the only person who had any chance of reading it for him was the woman he mistreated. A woman who left him to die in a fevor brought about by his wounds suffered from his own diabolical manipulations.
 In the end, Oldman's reign of evil was brought down by his own hand.
 
 The blind messenger continued with his trek and delivered the word to the place he was instructed to do so...by faith.
 
 What I disliked was the ending...after ALL of that trouble, the people at the prison merely copied the book...and placed it on a shelf alongside other holy works.
 IF this was a story about faith and the power of religion to do good...it would have been in the hands of a reader reciting its passages to a congregation as they communally sought to rebuild the shattered world.
 A book on the shelf...useless.
 But, I guess that's the role the girl will take as she treks back out into the wilderness.
 
 
 As for the Road. The book was far more terrifying. And, I think they omitted a key line. After the black traveler stole their belongings at the beach, the father was walking off with his clothing after recovering their belongings and took revenge on the thief. At that point, the boy pleaded to show mercy to the thief and commented; 'If we're the good guys, how come we never do anything good?'
Steeeeve

What did you get out of the movie?
That it was well done....good acting, interesting and unique plot, entertaining, etc. I honestly don't get any little life lessons out of movies. 
 
 It was certainly one of the best movies I've seen this year...that and Toy Story 3 :)
